questions.text: A 42-year-old woman who presented with a 3-month history of a painless firm lump in her breast's upper outer quadrant underwent breast conservative surgery and is now awaiting instructions on follow-up. What is the recommended advice regarding the follow-up for this patient?

choices.text: Annual mammograms of the treated and contralateral breast
Annual mammograms of the contralateral breast only
Annual mammograms of the contralateral breast only and Serum tumor markers
Annual mammograms of the treated and contralateral breast and Serum tumor markers

questions.solution:
For a patient with the given clinical scenario after treatment of breast cancer, the recommended follow-up advice consists of a routine physical examination once in 3 months for the first two years and annual mammograms of the treated and contralateral breast.

Mammography is the only imaging modality necessary for follow-up after breast cancer surgery. There is currently no role for tumour markers, serum investigations, or any other imaging studies like bone scans in follow-up.

Women who have had a mastectomy, including simple mastectomy, modified radical mastectomy, and radical mastectomy would not need further routine screening mammograms on that side, but will still need to have a yearly mammogram on the remaining breast.

The guidelines for follow-up are as follows,

Physical examination:

  • For the first 2 years: once every 3 months
  • For 3-5 years: once every 6 months
  • After 5 years: Annually

Mammography: Annually

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

Related Pearl: Hormonal therapy in breast carcinoma given for ER/PR-positive cases

Role:

  • Reduce risk of recurrence
  • Reduce risk of contralateral breast cancer
  • Reduce risk of progression of in situ to invasive carcinoma
Selective estrogen- receptor modulator Aromatase inhibitors Ovarian suppression/ ablation
  • Tamoxifen
  • Raloxifen

  • Fenoxifen
  • Anastrazole
  • Letrozole
  • Exemestane
  • Oophorectomy

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. His vitals are stable but he complains of flank pain and blood in the urine. On examination, there was some abrasion on the abdomen in the right iliac and lumbar region. A CECT was done which revealed a laceration in the right kidney extending to the collecting ducts with some urine extravasation. He was managed conservatively. Follow-up imaging revealed the presence of a persistent urinoma. What is the next best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient in the given question has renal laceration with urine extravasation, indicating that he had a grade 4 renal injury.

During the follow-up of grade IV injury, a persistent urinoma should be managed with the placement of an internal ureteral stent. In patients not cured by ureteral stenting, percutaneous nephrostomy or transcutaneous drain may be required.

Management of renal injuries

  • Grading of injury through CECT
  • If hemodynamically stable
    • Conservative management - Bedrest & hemodynamic monitoring
    • In grade IV, a repeat CT scan to ensure the extravasation of urine has resolved.
  • If hemodynamically unstable
    • Surgical exploration and repair
    • In grade V, nephrectomy.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Kidney Injury Scale

GRADE  

 INJURY DESCRIPTION
I

Contusion

Microscopic or gross hematuria, urologic studies normal
  Hematoma

Subcapsular, nonexpanding, without parenchymal laceration
II

Hematoma

Nonexpanding perirenal hematoma confined to renal retroperitoneum
  Laceration

 <1 cm parenchymal depth of renal cortex without urinary extravasation
III

Laceration 

>1 cm depth of renal cortex, without collecting system rupture or urinary extravasation
IV Laceration

Parenchymal laceration extending through the renal cortex, medulla, and collecting system
  Vascular

Main renal artery or vein injury, with contained hemorrhage
V Laceration Completely shattered kidney

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with hoarseness and a low-pitched voice. She is a singer and a known smoker. Her laryngoscopy findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The laryngoscopy findings show diffuse bilateral edema of the vocal folds suggestive of Reinke's edema.

It occurs due to edema of the subepithelial space (Reinke’s space) of the vocal cords in the glottis.

Key clinical features

  • History of smoking and/or voice abuse.
  • Hoarseness is the most common symptom.
  • Patients use false cords for voice production and this gives them a low-pitched and rough voice.

On indirect laryngoscopy, both vocal cords show diffuse symmetrical swellings. They appear as fusiform swellings with a pale translucent look. Ventricular bands may appear hyperemic and hypertrophic and may hide the view of the true cords.

Treatment

  • Voice rest and cessation of smoking
  • Decortication of the vocal cords, i.e. removal of a strip of epithelium
  • Speech therapy for proper voice production.

Other options

Option B: Laryngeal papilloma/ squamous papilloma are benign tumors of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). They occur in children (juvenile papillomatosis) as well as adults. Patients present with hoarseness, dyspnea or stridor.

Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white “grape-like” projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. 

The image below shows laryngeal papilloma. 

Option C: A Vocal polyp is caused by vocal abuse or misuses such as sudden shouting resulting in hemorrhage and submucosal edema. It presents with hoarseness and diplophonia. In case of a large polyp, dyspnea, stridor or choking may occur.

On indirect laryngoscopy, they appear as soft, smooth, mobile, and pedunculated mass arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord. They are mostly unilateral.

Treatment is by surgical excision followed by speech therapy.

The image below shows a vocal polyp.

Option D: Vocal nodules (Singer's or Screamer's nodes) are also caused by vocal abuse or misuse. It most commonly affects teachers, actors, singers, vendors, and talkative school children. Patients complain of hoarseness, vocal fatigue, and neck pain during prolonged talking.

On indirect laryngoscopy, they appear as a greyish or white pin-head-sized mass arising from the free edge of the vocal cord at the junction between anterior one-third and posterior two-third of the vocal cord. They are mostly symmetrical (bilateral).

Small vocal nodules are treated conservatively with speech therapy. Large ones are treated by surgical excision followed by speech therapy.

The image below shows symmetrical vocal nodules.

questions.text: The histopathological slide obtained from the lungs of a patient who died from respiratory failure is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological slide shows Masson bodies which are seen in cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.

Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is synonymous with the previously popular designation bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP).

Histologically COP is characterized by the presence of Masson bodies. These are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, alveoli and bronchioles along with foci of fibrosis. There is no interstitial fibrosis or honeycombing of lung. The clinical presentation of COP is the development of nonspecific systemic and respiratory symptoms. It is associated with filling of the lung alveoli that are visible on a chest x-ray as patchy consolidation.

Other options

Option A - CMV-associated organizing pneumonia

CMV is a β-group herpesvirus. It primarily affects the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis). It commonly affects neonates and immunocompromised people (e.g., transplant recipients, HIV- infected individuals). The histopathology slide below shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo - owl’s eye.

Option B - Giant cell pneumonia

Also known as Hecht's pneumonia, it is a fatal but rare complication of measles. It is seen in children with immunodeficiency or severe malnutrition. The postmortem examination (autopsy) shows multinucleated giant cells or Warthin–Finkeldey giant cells lining the alveoli (air sacs) of the lungs. The histopathology slide below shows giant cells.

Option C - Silicosis

It results from the inhalation of crystalline silica. The slide below shows a silicotic nodule characterised by a central area of whorled collagen fibres, with a more peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages and a rim of lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old obese woman who recently joined a weight loss program presents with pain along the anterior and medial aspects of her tibia. The pain increases while doing jogging and walking on the treadmill for long periods. On examination, there is diffuse tenderness along the tibial shaft. A plain X-ray radiograph of her leg is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient with diffuse tibial pain and a normal x-ray is the shin splint or medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS). 

MTSS is a stress injury of the tibia which occurs due to the frequent overuse of lower limbs. It is commonly seen in athletes and military personnel.

Risk factors for MTSS

  • High body mass index (BMI)
  • An increase in training volume or intensity
  • Female gender
  • Previous history of MTSS

Exercise-induced diffuse pain along the distal two-thirds of the medial tibial border is typical. Since it is a stress injury, the radiograph of the leg appears normal.

MTSS often leads to stress fractures of the tibia. When this occurs, the pain increases in intensity becomes localized and is associated with swelling.

It is treated conservatively. The patient should take physical rest and modify daily activities to avoid repetitive and load-bearing exercises. Other modalities being studied include ice massage and ultrasound therapy. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the lower limb

questions.text: Mr. Kumar presented with complaints of itchy eyes since 1 year. His symptoms are worse in the morning with some blurring of vision which quickly improves on blinking. On examination, his eyelids appear red and swollen with cylindrical dandruff-like scaling around the base of eyelashes. The rest of the eye examination was unremarkable. Which of the following organisms is linked to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic anterior blepharitis of the seborrheic type linked to Demodex folliculorum.

Chronic blepharitis is characterized by the inflammation of the eyelids associated with eye irritation. It is of two types:

  • Posterior blepharitis
    • Inflammation of inner portion of the eyelid (more common)
    • Caused by meibomian gland dysfunction
    • Associated with acne rosacea
  • Anterior blepharitis
    • Inflammation of base of eyelashes
    • Two types
      • Seborrhoeic type which is associated with dermatitis. This is characterized by dandruff-like skin changes and greasy scales.
      • Staphylococcal type is characterized by fibrinous scales and crust around the eyelashes caused by colonization of the eyelids by Staphylococcus aureus and CoNS

Parasitic causes of blepharitis

  • Blepharitis acarica caused by Demodex folliculorum - A key clinical feature of this infestation is the presence of dandruff-like scaling at the base of eye-lashes.
  • Phthiriasis palpebrarum caused by crab louse.

Image: Swollen and inflamed eyelid suggestive of blepharitis

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a history of end-stage renal disease due to diabetic renal disease is admitted to the hospital with 1 day of abdominal pain and fever. She has been on continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis for the last 6 months. She reports that for the last day she has had a poor return of dialysate and is feeling bloated. Her vital signs include a pulse rate of 105 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 130/65, and a temperature of 38.8°C. Her abdomen is slightly distended and diffusely tender with rebound tenderness. A sample of dialysate reveals a WBC count of 400/μL with 80% neutrophils. Empiric intraperitoneal antibiotic therapy should include antibiotics against which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD)-associated peritonitis likely to have been caused by Staphylococcus aureus. 

CAPD is usually caused most commonly by skin organisms such as Staphylococcus species that migrate into the peritoneal fluid via the device, unlike primary and secondary bacterial peritonitis which are caused by endogenous bacteria.

Clinically, there is an acute onset of symptoms with diffuse abdominal pain and peritoneal signs.

Laboratory analysis reveals a cloudy dialysate with >100 WBC/μL and >50% neutrophils. It should be cultured in blood culture media. Organisms most commonly isolated are gram-positive organisms such as S. epidermidis, followed by S. aureus, and Streptococcus spp.

Therefore, Empirical therapy should be directed against Staphylococcus aureus along with CoNS and gram negative Bacilli. An initial empirical regimen could include vancomycin with an aminoglycoside. IV antibiotics should be added in severe infections. Catheter removal should be considered if the patient does not adequately respond to antibiotic therapy within four days.

Peritonitis is the most common reason for discontinuing CAPD and switching to hemodialysis. Other complications of peritoneal dialysis are-

  1. Catheter blockage
  2. Weight gain and poor diabetic control (dialysate fluid has high sugar content)
  3. Pleural effusion
  4. Metabolic disturbances: Hypoproteinemia, hyperglycemia.

questions.text: The likely diagnosis based on the serum electrophoresis image is:
questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates a sharp peak ("church spire” or M band) in the gamma globulin region. This is characteristically seen in a patient with multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma involves a malignant proliferation of plasma cells, resulting in excessive production of abnormal immunoglobulins, causing a spike called the M band.

Certain common diseases and their electrophoretic pattern:

Condition  Electrophoretic pattern
Chronic infections Smooth increase in gamma globulins
Multiple myeloma Gamma globulin part is increased (M BAND)
Liver cirrhosis Reduced albumin and compensatory increase in globulin
Primary immune deficiency Gamma globulin reduced
α1 antitrypsin deficiency α1 band is thin and even lost sometimes

questions.text: A 2-year-old macrocephalic child was brought to the ER with seizures. The child has stiffness and spasticity of both limbs along with delayed milestones. Bilateral symmetrical white matter signal hyperintensity with a frontal predominance is noted on T2 MRI. Unfortunately despite resuscitation, the child passed away. The autopsy image of the brain of the child is as shown below and shows macroencephaly. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A macrocephalic child with developmental delay, seizures, and T2 MRI showing bilateral symmetrical white matter signal hyperintensity with a frontal predominance and macroencephaly is indicative of Alexander's Disease.

Early involvement of subcortical white matter with the predilection for the frontal lobe is characteristic of Alexander's disease. The disease progresses posteriorly to parietal white matter and internal and external capsules with the formation of cysts.

The autopsy specimen shows macroencephaly and periventricular demyelination (brownish discoloration around the cerebral ventricles)

  • Dysmyelinating diseases, or leukodystrophies, are inherited neurodegenerative disorders that affect the integrity of myelin in the brain and peripheral nerves. They can be seen in lysosomal storage diseases, peroxisomal disorders, and diseases caused by mitochondrial dysfunction.
  • The most common of these are presented below.
  • Metachromatic leukodystrophy: Late infantile (most common), juvenile, and adult types. Symmetric confluent areas of T2 hyperintensity in the periventricular white matter. Radiating T2-hypointense lines through the demyelinated deep white matter represent sparing of the perivascular white matter and result in the tigroid and leopard skin patterns when imaged in the long axis or cross-section, respectively. Subcortical U fibers are spared.
  • X-linked Adrenoleukodystrophy: Affects the white matter of the central nervous system, adrenal cortex, and testes.
  • Canavan Disease: Spongiform leukodystrophy (extensive vacuolization of subcortical white matter). There is preferential involvement of the subcortical U fibers early on.
  • MELAS Syndrome: Mitochondrial Encephalomyopathy with Lactic Acidosis and Stroke-like episodes.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhoea, menorrhagia, and infertility. After ruling out other possible causes, the gynecologist performs laparoscopy during which he finds the following lesions in the pelvis. Which of the following drugs can be administered intra-nasally to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Nafarelin is administered via nasal spray and it is approved for use in endometriosis and central precocious puberty. Nafarelin is used in a 200-μg twice-daily nasal spray regimen.

The diagnosis of the given condition is Endometriosis. The laparoscopic picture shows powder-burn spots pathognomic of endometriosis. Endometriosis presents with unexplained infertility, dysmenorrhea, and menorrhagia.

A new agent, elagolix sodium, is a nonpeptide oral GnRH antagonist that is recently approved by the FDA for the management of moderate to severe pain associated with endometriosis.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (glands and stroma) outside the uterus. It is an estrogen-dependent disease of the childbearing age group. The most common site of occurrence is the ovary followed by the pouch of Douglas.

Risk factors for the development of endometriosis

  • Family history
  • Nulliparity
  • Prolonged exposure to endogenous estrogen
    • Early menarche and
    • Late menopause
  • Estrogen therapy
  • In utero exposure to Diethyl stilbesterol (DES)

Key clinical features

  • Dysmenorrhoea
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Infertility
  • Pain during urination or defecation,
  • Constipation or diarrhea
  • Irregular bleeding.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis has been a visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. Laparoscopy is also the investigation of choice in endometriosis.

Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:

  • To detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
  • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging.
  • To take biopsy
  • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation, removal

Other investigations:

  • CA-125 levels are raised in endometriosis.
  • Monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) levels are raised in the peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.
  • MRI
  • Colour doppler
  • Anti-endometrial antibodies 

Treatment of endometriosis:

Medical management:

Minimal disease Moderate/Severe disease

NSAIDs (drug of choice) GnRH agonist (drug of choice)

OCPs (Pain with menstrual complaints) Progesterone (First drug to start)

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analogue
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D: Danazol
  • G: Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P: Progesterone

Surgical management:

Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormones delay pregnancy.

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy.

 

Routes of administration of other GnRH agonists are 

  • Buserelin - intranasal spray and Subcutaneous implant 
  • Histrelin - subcutaneous implant
  • Goserelin - subcutaneous implant
  • Leuprolide- IM and subcutaneous implant

Some GnRH antagonists are

  • Cetrorelix
  • Degarelix
  • Ganirelix 

 All GnRH antagonists are administered subcutaneously.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text:
A 20-month-old child was diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition and was started on treatment. When can the child's treatment be considered complete?
  1. There is no edema for at least two weeks
  2. There is no edema for at least 4 weeks
  3. Weight for length reaches - 2 S.D or higher
  4. Mid-upper arm circumference is more than 12.5 cm
  5. Mid-upper arm circumference is more than 13.5 cm
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 3 and 4.

A child with SAM may be considered to have completed treatment when:

  • There is no edema for at least 2 weeks +
  • Weight-for-height (or length) reaches -2 SD or higher or mid-upper-arm circumference is more than 12.5 cm.

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by WHO as any of the following:

  • Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
  • Presence of bipedal edema
  • Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm

Treatment: The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

Phases: 

Initial stabilization phase :

(mnemonic: SHIELDED- Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia), Hypothermia, Infection, ELectrolyte imbalance, DEhydration, Deficiency of nutrients)

  • Focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions.
  • 2-7 days of inpatient treatment

Rehabilitation phase: 

  • Focuses on rebuilding wasted tissues
  • Takes several weeks

Steps:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (Blood glucose level<54 mg/dl): if symptomatic give 10% Dextrose IV 5ml/kg; Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (Formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care (“kangaroo technique”) or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal - Rehydration solution for malnutrition (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (4 mmol/kg/day) and magnesium (0.6 mmol/kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14 if there is presence of xeropthalmia.
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
  • Start cautious feeding : Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 to provide 130 mL/kg/day,100 kcal/kg/day, and 1 to 1.5 g protein/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal edema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to home-based diet

questions.text: During your visit to the CHC, you notice the ANM takes one frozen vial of a vaccine, as control, and another vial of the same vaccine.  She shakes both the vials and is trying to compare the rate of sedimentation of solutes in both vials. For which of the below-mentioned vaccines would you not be performing this test?
questions.solution:
The freeze damage to vaccines is detected by the Shake test. It is used for all freeze-sensitive vaccines - all the 'T-series' vaccines. The shake test is not used for the MMR vaccine.

The freeze damage to vaccines is detected by Shake test.

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in test vial is slower than the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.
  • Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze-sensitive. Examples: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Liquid Haemophilus influenza type b (Hib), Hepatitis B.

Related Pearl: Measles vaccine

Measles vaccine: 

  • Type: Live attenuenated, lyophilized (freeze dried), vaccine (Tissue culture vaccine- chick embryo or Human diploid cell line).

  • Strains used: 1. Edmonston Zagreb strain (most common). 

                            2. Schwartz strain.

                            3. Moraten strain.

  • Dose: 0.5ml.

  • Route: Subcutaneous.

  • Site: Right arm (usually).

  • Age of administration in National immunization schedule (India): 9 months (can be lowered to 6-9 months in epidemics and malnutrition) and 16-24 months.

  • Diluent for reconstitution: Distilled water or sterile water. (To be used within 4 hours after reconstitutuion).

  • Measles (and MMR) vaccine can lead to Toxic shock syndrome.

  • Measles vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

  • Cold chain temperature for storage: +2 to +8 degree Celcius.

  • Protective efficacy: >90% with one dose; >99% with two doses.

  • Duration of protection: Life long.

  • IP of vaccine induced measles: 7 days.

  • Ideal gap between two successive doses: 6 months.

questions.text: A patient with long standing liver cirrhosis presents with renal dysfunction and is suspected to have hepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following statements regarding its management is true?

choices.text: Treatment involves concomitant liver and renal transplant
Definitive treatment of this condition is renal transplant
Recovery of kidney function can occur spontaneously post liver transplantation
Terlipressin has no role in management of this condition

questions.solution:
Renal function can recover spontaneously in cases of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) after a liver transplantation. 

Hepatorenal syndrome is a progressive renal failure in patients with acute or chronic liver disease. The diagnostic criteria for hepatorenal syndrome include:

  • Cirrhosis with ascites
  • Diagnosis of acute kidney injury (AKI)
    • Increase in serum creatinine of ≥ 0.3mg/dL in 48 hours, OR
    • 50% increase in serum creatinine from baseline within 7 days
  • Absence of shock
  • No evidence of recent use of nephrotoxic agents
  • Absence of intrinsic renal disease
  • Other criteria that also apply:
    • Urine red cell excretion of fewer than 50 cells per high power field (when no urinary catheter is in place) and protein excretion less than 500 mg/day
    • Lack of improvement in kidney function after volume expansion with intravenous albumin (1 g/kg of body weight per day up to 100 g/day) for at least two days and withdrawal of diuretics

Management of hepatorenal syndrome includes:

  • Norepinephrine
  • Octreotide
  • Terlipressin (Option D)
  • Midodrine
  • Intravenous albumin 
  • Liver transplantation - definitive treatment

Renal transplantation (Options A and B) is not indicated in HRS.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient is brought with ataxia. He recalls an episode of diarrhea last week. On examination, the patient has the eye findings shown below and absent knee jerk reflexes. Which of the following is true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: Antibodies against a ganglioside component will be present
The preceding diarrhea is unrelated to the condition
Electrodiagnostic study will reveal increased sensory response

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of ataxia, absent knee jerk, fixed and dilated pupil, and a history of diarrhea is likely to have Miller-Fisher syndrome (MFS). MFS is a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). In MFS, antibodies are seen against GQ1b, which is a ganglioside component of the nerve.

GBS is progressive, symmetric muscle weakness with absent or reduced deep tendon reflexes of variable severity. It is typically an ascending paralysis that may lead to severe respiratory muscle weakness.

In MFS, like GBS, symptoms may be preceded by a viral illness (upper respiratory tract infections or diarrhea). It classically presents as a triad of

  • Ataxia
  • Areflexia
  • Ophthalmoplegia.

The condition is usually not associated with weakness, and even if present, is very mild. It is strongly associated with antibodies to ganglioside. The prognosis for Miller-Fisher syndrome is usually good. Recovery occurs in 8-12 weeks. Some individuals are left with residual deficits. 

Electrodiagnostic studies will reveal reduced or absent sensory responses without slowing the conduction velocity. Motor nerve conduction abnormalities may be present if there is associated weakness. 

Treatment for Miller-Fisher syndrome is identical to treatment for Guillain-Barré syndrome: intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis and supportive care.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother for evaluation of hair growth. Her mother noticed pubic hair growth while bathing her yesterday and is concerned that there is something wrong. Further examination reveals a girl child at 95th centile for height, tanner stage III breast development, and tanner stage IV axillary and pubic hair. Which of the following is incorrect about her condition?

choices.text: The next step after physical examination is evaluation of bone age
Secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 is considered precocious puberty
Fasting glucose levels and HbA1C levels should be done in this patient
Serum FSH, LH and thyroid profile should be obtained in this patient

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a girl child with precocious puberty. Fasting glucose levels and HbA1C levels are not recommended in the workup of precocious puberty and are rather used in the evaluation of a patient with polycystic ovarian syndrome.

Precocious menstruation is one of the menstrual cycle irregularities. Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years. Precocious puberty in boys is the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of nine years. 

Classification:

  • Complete precocious puberty: Idiopathic, familial, sporadic, genetic, congenital/acquired lesions of the hypothalamic and pituitary glands, specific syndromes (McCune Albright)
  • Incomplete: Premature thelarche, adrenarche, menarche
  • Pseudoprecocious (GnRH independent): Ovarian tumors, Adrenal hyperplasia/neoplasm, hypothyroidism, hepatoblastoma, iatrogenic-estrogen administration

Investigations:

  • Radiograph of the wrist for bone age
  • Thyroid function tests
  • EEG and MRI of the skull
  • Adrenal function tests
  • Pelvic ultrasonography
  • GnRH, FSH, LH and estrogen levels

Management:

  • Injection DMPA
  • Cyproterone acetate
  • GnRH agonists
  • Calcium and Vitamin D supplements

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male patient comes to the clinic for preoperative evaluation before bariatric surgery. He has a complex medical history and takes many medications. He was diagnosed with schizophrenia at the age of 18 on risperidone and bronchial asthma at the age of 10 for which he takes a daily SABA and ICS. Two years ago, he was found to have an abnormal lipid profile. Subsequently, he had an anterior wall myocardial infarction for which he received percutaneous coronary intervention with stenting. On examination, the patient is obese, pulse rate is 90/min, blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg and respiratory rate is 20/min. Read the following about anesthetic choices in this patient and choose the correct statements.
  1. Ketamine is contraindicated in this patient because of bronchial asthma
  2. Etomidate can be used in this patient with a history of heart disease
  3. Ketamine is safe to use in patients with psychiatric disorders
  4. Use of propofol in this patient is associated with increased risk of pancreatitis
  5. Ketamine relaxes bronchial smooth muscles and can be considered in this patient
questions.solution:
This patient with a complex medical history needs careful consideration of the contraindications to the use of certain anesthetic agents. 

Ketamine is not contraindicated in this patient with bronchial asthma but history of schizophrenia precludes its use in this patient

Contraindications for use of ketamine:

  • Raised intracranial pressure
  • Open globe injury- as ketamine raises intraocular pressure
  • Vascular aneurysm surgery- because of the possible sudden change in arterial blood pressure
  • Psychiatric disease, such as schizophrenia
  • Hyperthyroidism -  exaggerated elevations in blood pressure and heart rate.
  • Ischemic heart disease - increase in myocardial oxygen consumption

Propofol has been associated with hypertriglyceridemia, which may predispose the patient to pancreatitis.

Risk factor for propofol-induced hypertriglyceridemia:

  • Old age
  • Longer ICU stay
  • Received propofol for a longer duration.

Hence it is essential to monitor serum triglyceride levels when propofol is used for prolonged duration or at higher infusion rates (especially in older patients).

As the patient has a history of coronary artery disease, the agent of choice is etomidate.

Etomidate is the most cardiac stableintravenous agent due to its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptor. The myocardial oxygen supply-to-demand ratio is well maintained. Hence, etomidate is the intravenous agent of choice in patients with coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, and cerebral vascular disease.

Disadvantages of etomidate:

  • Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)
  • Myoclonus
  • Adrenocortical suppression
  • Epileptogenic potential

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are correct with respect to the cardiac cycle, heart sounds, and the waveforms seen on the ECG?

1) Timing of S1 heart sound corresponds temporally to the occurrence of QRS wave in ECG

2) Timing of S2 heart sound corresponds temporally to the end of T wave in ECG

3) 'v' wave of JVP mirrors the rise in atrial pressure before the tricuspid valve opens

4) The ‘c’ wave of JVP is seen during the first phase of the ventricular diastole.
questions.solution:
The statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct.

As clear from Wigger's diagram below, S1 corresponds the timing of S1 heart sound corresponds temporally to the occurrence of QRS wave in ECG.

Similarly, the timing of the S2 heart sound corresponds to the end of the T wave in ECG. 

The statement D is incorrect as the ‘c’ wave of JVP is seen during the isovolumetric contraction (with all valves closed) phase when the ventricular muscle continues to contract. 

The Cardiac Cycle:

Diastole 

  • Protodiastole
    Before the semilunar valve closes, even though ventricular muscle is relaxed, blood flow into great vessels is due to the momentum of blood.
  • Iso-volumetric Relaxation
    The ventricular muscle continues to relax, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed.
  • Ventricular Filling
    Isovolumetric relaxation ends when the ventricular pressure falls below the atrial pressure and the AV valves open, permitting the ventricles to fill.
  • Atrial Systole
    During the last third of diastole, the atria contract and give additional thrust to the inflow of blood into the ventricles. It correlates with the 'a' wave in JVP.

Systole 

  • Isovolumetric Contraction
    The ventricular muscle continues to contract, even though the ventricular volume does not change, with all valves closed. 
    It correlates with the ‘c’ wave of JVP.
  • Ventricular Ejection
    When the ventricular pressures rise above aortic and pulmonary pressures the valves open, and ventricular ejection begins. Peak pressures in the left and right ventricles are about 120 and 25 mmHg, respectively. 

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 1 week-old neonate was brought to the tertiary care hospital with the following findings and a head circumference less than -3SD. The mother informs that she had been taking a drug for a neurological condition, for the last 4 years. Which of the following drugs is likely to be implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
The drug implicated in this case is phenytoin.

The mother would have been taking phenytoin during pregnancy which can cross the placenta and cause fetal hydantoin syndrome as shown in the image.

In fetal hydantoin syndrome, the child may be small at birth with increased hair on the body and face facial features include a flat nasal bridge, an underdeveloped vertical groove in the centre of the upper lip (philtrum), malformed ears, downward-slanting eyes, which are spaced widely (hypertelorism), strabismus, ptosis and epicanthal folds. Other features include microcephaly and growth deficiencies like underdeveloped fingers and toes, malformed nails.

The child would have varying degrees of developmental delay and the risk of an affected child having neurological deficits, cleft lip, cleft palate and heart defects very high. They may be an increased risk of the occurrence of benign or malignant tumours, such as neuroblastoma and Wilms tumour.

Side effects of phenytoin include:

  • Hirsutism
  • Hypersensitivity reactions
  • Osteomalacia
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome 

Dose-related toxicity of phenytoin causes the following:

  • Ataxia, vertigo, diplopia, and nystagmus (most characteristic)

Other options:

Option A: Maternal use of Lithium leads to Ebstein's anomaly where there is downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve into the right ventricle and macrosomia.

Options B and D: Levetiracetam and Lamotrigine are relatively safe in pregnancy and do not seem to cause neural tube defects.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents with the following lesions on the back and similar multiple, nodulocystic lesions on the face. She has tried various remedies for this condition like chemical peeling, topical and oral antibiotics, but there was no respite. She requests you to prescribe the most effective drug for this condition. You decide to start her on oral isotretinoin after performing a baseline evaluation of serum lipids, serum transaminases, and CBC. You would be correct to do all of the following except:

choices.text: Inform the patient to do monthly pregnancy tests while on the drug
Inform the patient to repeat testing of serum lipids, serum transaminases, and CBC again in 6 months
Ask the patient to take the drug along with high-fat meals
Ask the patient to delay pregnancy as this is a teratogenic drug

questions.solution:
Baseline evaluation of serum lipids, transaminases, and CBC should be done before starting any systemic retinoids. These values should be checked monthly for the first 3–6 months and once every 3 months thereafter.

Systemic absorption of isotretinoin is improved when taken with a fatty meal. Patients on isotretinoin should be asked to delay pregnancy as this is a teratogenic drug. Monthly pregnancy tests should be done while on the drug.

 Acne is a multifactorial condition characterized by excess sebum production, epithelial hyperkeratinization, cutibacterium acnes colonization in the pilosebaceous unit, and inflammation. Isotretinoin is an oral-systemic retinoid that has been approved for the treatment of recalcitrant and nodular acne vulgaris and is remarkably effective in severe acne. It can induce prolonged remissions after a single course of therapy. Clinical effects are seen within 1–3 months of starting therapy. Systemic absorption is improved when taken with a high-fat meal.

Mucocutaneous side effects like cheilitis, xerosis, blepharoconjunctivitis, cutaneous photosensitivity, photophobia, myalgia, arthralgia, headaches, alopecia, nail fragility, and increased susceptibility to staphylococcal infections can be seen with use. Retinoid dermatitis can develop which is characterized by erythema, pruritus, and scaling. Very rarely, patients can also develop pseudotumor cerebri, especially when systemic retinoids are taken with antibiotics like tetracyclines.

Systemic retinoids are highly teratogenic and no dose is safe during pregnancy. Absolute contraindications include pregnant women, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding mothers. Two negative pregnancy tests (on separate occasions) are required for females of childbearing age before starting acitretin or isotretinoin.

Serum lipid elevation is the most common laboratory abnormality. Elevated transaminases, decreased thyroid hormone, and leukopenia is less common.

questions.text: What is the 2030 target of the India Newborn Action Plan with regards to the stillbirth rate?
questions.solution:
The India Newborn Action Plan targets to achieve a stillbirth rate of < 10/ 1000 live births and neonatal mortality rate of < 10/ 1000 live births (single-digit SBR and NMR) by 2030.

This program was launched to reduce preventable newborn deaths and stillbirths. It provides the following:

  • Pre-conception and antenatal care
  • Care during labor and childbirth
  • Immediate newborn care
  • Care of healthy newborn
  • Care of small and sick newborn
  • Care beyond newborn survival
